title: Angelina Jolie fought to find the perfect Russian Red lips in 'Maleficent 2'
text:
CLOSE Disney's live-action “Maleficent: Mistress of Evil” is a fantasy adventure that picks up several years after “Maleficent.” Disney

LOS ANGELES – Even before Angelina Jolie showed up to reprise her role as the infamous dark fairy Maleficent, there was a lengthy confab over the red lips that have been the character's signature since she debuted as the villain in Disney's 1959 animated film "Sleeping Beauty."

Director Joachim Ronning wanted to change the "iconic" lips seen in 2014's "Maleficent" to a less shiny but still deep-red shade for the sequel, "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil" (in theaters Friday).

"I wanted to keep what I love about Maleficent but also to take it to the next level," Ronning says. "It’s Maleficent 2.0."

Angelina Jolie will make you cry: She explains her emotional farewell to college-bound Maddox

Is 'Maleficent 2' good? Critics praise Angelina Jolie's 'fierce fairy tale'

Angelina Jolie returns as the dark fairy in "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil." (Photo: DISNEY)

He learned Jolie's feelings were equally passionate about the character that brought the superstar her biggest box-office opening weekend ($69.4 million).

"Believe me, there was hours and hours discussing her lips. Definitely," Ronning says. "I felt in the first film, (the lips) were a bit saturated. I wanted to make them feel a little more natural, a little cooler and darker – but keeping them the red, red, red."

Ronning says he and Jolie went back and forth before agreeing upon the film's no-shine MAC Matte Russian Red lipstick.

"It's so important to her. So it was pretty much Angelina and I, battling it out. But at the end of the day, we agreed. We changed the color a bit," says Ronning, who notes that the decision ultimately rested with Jolie, one of the film's producers. "When she gets happy, then I get happy. That’s the order of things."

Angelina Jolie shows off her Maleficent power collar. (Photo: DISNEY)

Most filmgoers won't notice the difference, but costume designer Ellen Mirojnick says the shade of lipstick is a big deal, as the red stands out against the stark black-and-white outfits worn by the vengeful character.

"This slight change informs every decision we made," Mirojnick says. "But it worked out so well."

Mirojnick's team was assigned the task of creating a more noticeable aspect of Maleficent 2.0: the stunning bone collar she wears to confront her rival Queen Ingrith (Michelle Pfeiffer) during a pivotal first meeting at the castle. A high collar has always been a Maleficent trademark. But the bird-boned look tipped in gold, worn over a black silk gown, was next level. It was needed in the faceoff with Ingrith, who wears a formidable bodice covered in diamonds and jewels.

Angelina Jolie's Maleficent squares off with Michelle Pfeiffer's Queen Ingrith. (Photo: JAAP BUITENDIJK/DISNEY)

"It speaks of power and intimidation," Mirojnick says. "Each queen is presented in their most powerful form."

As tensions increased in the film, Ronning added length and power to Maleficent's already formidable wings. The sequel reveals that Maleficent isn't the only winged fairy as a whole colony of dark fey (led by Chiwetel Ejifor and Ed Skrein), driven into hiding by humans, step out to back her.

Chiwetel Ejiofor plays horned fairy Conall in "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil." (Photo: DISNEY)

The increased flight time, along with more fairies, meant some problems as Jolie filmed on wires with her horned co-stars.

"There were times Angelina and I would be flying around on the wires, and we’d get our horns locked," Skrein says. "We would literally get entangled."
